pros: Benefits, work hours, work environment, and management. There's much more but to keep this brief, I've listed my main pros.
cons: FQHC pay. This is an amazing organization that helps the needed community so i can understand the pay but I wish it was a bit higher. A lot of people work here because pay isn't as important as helping the community (some people being family members even).

pros: Good mission Longstanding company Room to grow in the organization
cons: Low classification with high expectation Low pay Executive Leadership

pros: Great mission and great patients
cons: Very poor organization, under staffed, poor management.

job_title: Medical Coding Compliance Specialist in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The mission is fantastic and they really follow the mission.
cons: Upper management can be a bit disorganized.

job_title: Panel Care Coordinator in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Vacation time after working 3 years.
cons: Wage is minimal in comparison to other health centers. The main reason why many leave.

pros: Reimburses for Continuing Medical Education.
cons: low wages, slow promotions, no accountability

review_title: Finally a company with a conscience
pros: They train their values and mission and actually use them as guiding principles through strategic planning and day to day activities.  People work together while keeping the patient as the focus.  Everyone I’ve met has a heart and a genuine interest in doing the right thing. They all care for community and people they serve, and still have fun while doing they work.  The executives have made some big changes recently providing new leadership opportunities to several staff.  They go out of their way to promote from within and even ensure some entry level staff have can get college training and enter new carriers.
cons:
Low wages, which is expected with non-profits.
There seems to be a lot of projects going in different direction without a lot of coordination.  Leadership is working to limit the volume and only take on what is necessary to achieve the strategic objectives, but the process is taking a bit of time.  I hope we can all hold out till things are under control.  There is a lot of confusion with shifting priorities.  The change management is great, but only with a focus and with realistic expectations of staff and the limited number of hours in a day.

pros:
The mission of VG is wonderful and all employees care about it.
Many people are kind and passionate.
New office setup/equipment 
Multiple corporate lunches
cons:
I came from large corporate backgrounds with structure, policy, formalization and standard business practice. This is not who VG is. This organization's mentality is one that 'shoots from the hip' and is some amateur in their business practices and models. Many employees have been their for a very long time, causing them to not move beyond their current business models and grow. They struggle with correct position titling, along with roles & responsibilities pertaining to accurate position description. VG is a place to gain a title such as manager or director and then move on to a larger corporation. VG moves at its own pace and is not comfortable with high paced action oriented individuals. 

Deeply embedded culture of unwillingness to grow and get better.
Core concepts of standard business practice is highly lacking.
On average 10% less pay for market value.
Benefits are way below average (health/PTO/401k)

I am not a bitter employee. There are some great people at VG and I was very excited to join. This organization just wasn't for me, personally or professionally.

review_title: Good place to work, but poor administration
pros: The mission is why physicians, physician assistants and nurse practitioners work here. The nurses and teams are also dedicated to the work and patients. If you truly want to work at a place where the focus is on patient care and mission driven, come work on a team here.
cons: Medical assistants are involved in gossip and unprofessional. The union works to keep unproductive staff here and encourages behavior that is unprofessional. I do not benefit from the union because I do my job well. Clinic staff and administration treat managers here very poorly-I would suggest you look at another place to work if you are a manager. Managers are often skilled with more training than some of the administration and I often hear of problems. Administration wants to implement changes and they don't take the time to listen to the staff and blame managers who do listen, for their own failures. I do not trust the directors at all.

review_title: Making a difference in the community
pros: Organization is very mission-driven.  Work/Life balance is good.  Management is approachable and open to new ideas.  These clinics really make a difference in the lives of patients and VG is a pioneer in the move to the Primary Care Home model of care.  The executive team cares greatly about staff satisfaction, as well.
cons: The way healthcare is provided is ever-evolving these days.  In the last few years many changes have come and gone at VG, and as in any industry, it can make staff uncomfortable and the turnover rate high.  Also, the organization's nonprofit status means funds are minimal for such things as bonuses and pay raises.

review_title: Not living up to their mission to serve the community
job_title: Panel Care Coordinator in Beaverton, OR
pros: The organization stood behind the mission, during training at least.  After the short term training, new employees received very little support, and if an employee found themselves facing a difficult situation out of their control with a sick child, they were terminated.
cons: Lack of employee support systems, management was unprofessional, many teams were involved in gossip, with more training, a new employee would have been able to successfully fulfil what had been presented as the mission of Virginia Garcia, which is the reason I pursued a career with them. Sorely disappointed.

review_title: Great place to work if you love peace, quiet, and isolation.
pros: Honestly, the patients was the only positive thing.
cons: The staff is not very friendly and it is a hard environment to work in. It is not a welcoming atmosphere AT ALL. Every time I walked down the hallway, people just glared at me. It took my supervisor 5 weeks to even say hello. In the interview, I was told nurses get to do a lot of hands-on interaction with patients, only to find out that most of the in-person interactions with patients are reserved for providers and medical assistants. So disappointing. Nurses at Virginia Garcia are basically on the phone ALL DAY. Do not work here if you are looking for a fast-paced work environment like the hospital. So glad I left.

pros: I love the mission of the organization. Most of the people truly care about the patients and making the organization a success. They do innovative things and try their best to provide access to patients.
cons:
The executive team has too many direct reports. They are spread too thin and can be hard to find time to meet with them.  
Okay benefits. The health plan is Kaiser and pretty affordable and you get a 403b company match after two years but that is the extent of the benefits. I get that it is a non-profit but there are no other perks to the organization.

review_title: Puts the "community" in Community Health Center
pros:
-Forwarding a noble and important cause impacting over 45,000 patients in Oregon: quality healthcare for those who need it most.
-A company culture of community, innovation and acceptance. Potlucks and other employee-led celebrations of each other are frequent!
-Organization respected by HRSA and NACHC for exceptional clinical quality performance metrics and advocacy.  
-Financially sound, sizable FQHC that has continued to grow and evolve in Oregon for over 40 years. 
-Exceptional benefits such as three weeks' vacation, Public Service Loan Forgiveness and EAP.
cons:
-Miscommunication or lack of communication during a "growth state" often resulted in confusion, unanticipated extra work and frustration for staff when I first started with VG, contributing to some divisions between different departments and groups within the organization. 

Communication within the organization improved significantly in my three years with VG, though, and I observed events like these less and less frequently.

-There is always work to do when trying to serve the underserved, and non-profits like VG must do so with limited resources. Not always being able to help everyone who need help and being witness to the impacts of poverty on people can sometimes be disheartening.

pros: Worthwhile mission with committed employees and management.  Good benefits-four weeks vacation after three years,fast growing with lots of opportunity for people who want to stay and grow.
cons: I  support unions but this one is the worst I've ever seen.  Top down decisions, no communication, instead of getting people involved they drive people out.  High dues, no service.  Too busy defending the dead beats.

review_title: Managers can't make a decision because everything has to go through the top - everything
pros: Great mission started by people who had good motivation.  Employees work really hard but soon move on because they have no control or input into the work.  Patients are the best.
cons: Top management from 1990 who operate as if there are only 50 employees.

pros: Everyone is aware of how important the mission is and believes it.  People truly care about their community and the organization's impact.  Patients come first!
cons: Can be stressful with much work added to an already full workloads.  Take moments to breathe, talk with coworkers who are all in the same boat.

review_title: Amazing organization, powerful mission, wonderful people
pros:
the mission attracts people who are service oriented, warm and caring
a strong sense of community among staff members
innovative, on the frontier of primary care renewal
cons: constant change within the organization programs, sometimes changes take a long time

pros: Love the people. The mission is real and in your face.
cons: So many people to help and not enough hours in the day

pros: Vacation!! You get 3 weeks off. That's so far the only benefit i've had working here.
cons: There is no growth, no training or cross training.

pros: Great community, friendly staff, committed nurses.
cons: High staff turn-over, including management, little flexibility for innovation.

pros: Help under-served populations and they gave good pharmacies for their patients.
cons: Poor communication with administration. Outer clinics alienated from admin. Benefits unequal among employees. Executives make middle 6 figures without experience or education. Supposed to take uninsured but almost impossible to get appt if you are uninsured.

pros: Fantastic workplace with great employees.
cons: Communication could be better.
